abstract_summ: As the exponent of the distance dependence grows, the model networks smoothly transition from the random network limit to the regular lattice limit.We introduce an epidemic spreading model on a network using concepts from percolation theory.We introduce an epidemic spreading model on a network using concepts from percolation theory.Unfortunately, most models assume random mixing patterns instead of the higher-order structures necessary to describe large events.We consider cumulative merging percolation (CMP), a long-range percolation process describing the iterative merging of clusters in networks, depending on their mass and mutual distance.
title_summ: Cumulative Merging Percolation and the Epidemic Transition of the Susceptible-Infected-Susceptible Model in NetworksSocial confinement and mesoscopic localization of epidemics on networksSpreading of infections on random graphs: A percolation-type model for COVID-19Two-level modeling of quarantineContact network models matching the dynamics of the COVID-19 spreadingSpreading of infections on random graphs: A percolation-type model for COVID-19
title_abstract_phrases: Spreading of infections on random graphs: A percolation-type model for COVID-19We introduce an epidemic spreading model on a network using concepts from percolation theory.Spreading of infections on random graphs: A percolation-type model for COVID-19We introduce an epidemic spreading model on a network using concepts from percolation theory.Contact network models matching the dynamics of the COVID-19 spreadingWe study the epidemic spreading on spatial networks where the probability that two nodes are connected decays with their distance as a power law.As the exponent of the distance dependence grows, the model networks smoothly transition from the random network limit to the regular lattice limit.Unfortunately, most models assume random mixing patterns instead of the higher-order structures necessary to describe large events.
